title: Judges Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 16.

questions.question: Where did Samson go and find a harlot according to Judges 16:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Gaza
questions.explanation: Judges 16:1 states that Samson went to Gaza and saw a harlot there.

questions.question: What did the Gazites plan to do to Samson in Judges 16:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Kill him in the morning
questions.explanation: Judges 16:2 says the Gazites waited all night, saying they would kill Samson when day came.

questions.question: What did Samson carry away from the city gate in Judges 16:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The doors and two posts
questions.explanation: Judges 16:3 describes Samson carrying the doors of the gate and the two posts on his shoulders.

questions.question: Who was the woman Samson loved in the valley of Sorek as mentioned in Judges 16:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Delilah
questions.explanation: Judges 16:4 clearly states that Samson loved a woman named Delilah in the valley of Sorek.

questions.question: What did the lords of the Philistines offer Delilah to find out the secret of Samson's strength according to Judges 16:5?
options: Eleven hundred pieces of silver each
questions.correctAnswer: Eleven hundred pieces of silver each
questions.explanation: Judges 16:5 records the lords of the Philistines promising Delilah eleven hundred pieces of silver each to entice Samson.

questions.question: According to Judges 16:7, what would cause Samson to become weak?
options: Being bound with seven green withs
questions.correctAnswer: Being bound with seven green withs
questions.explanation: Judges 16:7 states Samson said if bound with seven green withs that were never dried, he would be weak.

questions.question: What was Samson’s reaction when Delilah told him the Philistines were upon him after binding him with green withs? (Judges 16:9)
questions.correctAnswer: He broke the withs easily
questions.explanation: Judges 16:9 describes Samson breaking the green withs as easily as a thread is broken by fire.

questions.question: What did Samson say would make him weak according to Judges 16:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Being bound with new ropes
questions.explanation: Judges 16:11 records Samson saying if bound with new ropes that were never used, he would be weak.

questions.question: What did Delilah do to Samson while he was sleeping as described in Judges 16:19?
questions.correctAnswer: Had his hair shaved off
questions.explanation: Judges 16:19 states Delilah called for a man to shave off Samson’s seven locks while he slept.

questions.question: What happened to Samson after Delilah’s act in Judges 16:21?
options: The Philistines blinded him and bound him
questions.correctAnswer: The Philistines blinded him and bound him
questions.explanation: Judges 16:21 describes the Philistines putting out Samson’s eyes and binding him with brass fetters.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 16:22 says Samson’s hair began to grow after he was shaven.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 16:22 clearly states that Samson’s hair began to grow again after being shaven.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 16:25, Samson was called to make sport for the Philistines during their celebration.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 16:25 says the Philistines called for Samson to make sport during their feast.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 16:28 records Samson praying to God for strength to be avenged just once more.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 16:28 shows Samson calling on the Lord to remember and strengthen him one last time for vengeance.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Judges 16:30: 'Let me die with the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 16:30 records Samson saying, 'Let me die with the Philistines' before pulling down the pillars.

questions.question: According to Judges 16:31, where was Samson buried?
questions.correctAnswer: Between Zorah and Eshtaol
questions.explanation: Judges 16:31 states Samson was buried between Zorah and Eshtaol in the burying place of Manoah his father.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation and repeatedly giving in. Based on Judges 16, what biblical truth would you share about perseverance?
options: Persistent urging can lead to revealing our weaknesses, so we must rely on God's strength, not our own.
Repeated temptation shows that God has abandoned us.
Strength comes from hiding our struggles from others.
Temptation is a sign to give up and avoid all challenges.
questions.correctAnswer: Persistent urging can lead to revealing our weaknesses, so we must rely on God's strength, not our own.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:16-17 shows how Samson was vexed by Delilah's persistent urging until he revealed his secret strength. This teaches the importance of depending on God’s power and guarding our hearts against temptation.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 teach about the importance of humility and seeking God's help in trials?
options: Samson's prayer for strength to defeat the Philistines shows reliance on God in weakness.
Samson relied solely on his own strength throughout.
God does not help those who have failed before.
Strength comes from trusting in human abilities alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson's prayer for strength to defeat the Philistines shows reliance on God in weakness.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:28-30 records Samson calling on the Lord to strengthen him one last time, showing the value of humility and prayer when facing trials.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to share personal struggles with someone untrustworthy. What practical wisdom does Judges 16 provide?
options: Be cautious because revealing your weaknesses to the wrong person can lead to harm.
Always share everything with everyone for support.
It is best to ignore problems completely.
Strength comes from boasting about your abilities.
questions.correctAnswer: Be cautious because revealing your weaknesses to the wrong person can lead to harm.
questions.explanation: Samson revealed his strength's secret to Delilah, who betrayed him (Judges 16:17-19), teaching the need for discretion in sharing personal matters.

questions.question: What does Judges 16 reveal about the consequences of disobedience and failing to trust God's protection?
options: Samson lost his strength and freedom because he let down his guard, showing the cost of disobedience.
God always protects us regardless of our choices.
Strength and success come from ignoring God’s guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson lost his strength and freedom because he let down his guard, showing the cost of disobedience.
questions.explanation: Verses 19-21 describe Samson’s loss of strength and capture after revealing his secret, highlighting the dangers of disobedience and misplaced trust.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 teach us about the biblical virtue of forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: Samson’s final act brings judgment rather than personal vengeance, showing God’s justice.
Samson refused to forgive and caused harm to himself.
Revenge is always the best response.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson’s final act brings judgment rather than personal vengeance, showing God’s justice.
questions.explanation: In Judges 16:30, Samson prays for strength to defeat the Philistines, indicating reliance on God’s justice rather than personal revenge.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged after failing in spiritual discipline. What does Samson’s story teach about perseverance in devotion despite setbacks?
options: Even after losing strength and sight, Samson’s hair began to grow again, symbolizing hope and restoration.
Failure means God has abandoned you permanently.
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary if you fail once.
Only perfect believers are useful to God.
questions.correctAnswer: Even after losing strength and sight, Samson’s hair began to grow again, symbolizing hope and restoration.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:22 shows Samson’s hair growing again, indicating God’s ongoing provision and hope despite failures.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 illustrate the importance of prayer and dependence on God in times of weakness?
options: Samson’s prayer in verse 28 demonstrates turning to God for strength when human power fails.
Prayer is only for the strong and successful.
Strength comes from ignoring God’s help.
God expects us to solve problems alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson’s prayer in verse 28 demonstrates turning to God for strength when human power fails.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:28 shows Samson praying to God for strength, teaching reliance on God especially in weakness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 16, Samson’s strength was in his hair because it was never cut as part of his Nazarite vow.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 16:17 explains that Samson’s strength depended on his Nazarite vow, including not cutting his hair.

questions.question: True or False: Delilah successfully discovered Samson’s secret strength on her first attempt by binding him with green withs.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Judges 16:9 shows Samson broke the green withs easily, so Delilah did not learn his secret on the first attempt.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Samson told Delilah that if he were ________, his strength would go from him and he would become weak like any other man.
questions.correctAnswer: shaven
questions.explanation: Judges 16:17 states that if Samson’s head were shaved, he would lose his strength and become weak.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 demonstrate the importance of integrity and honesty in relationships?
options: Samson’s repeated lies to Delilah led to his downfall, showing the danger of deceit.
Lying is acceptable if it protects us.
Honesty is not important in difficult situations.
Deceiving others always leads to success.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson’s repeated lies to Delilah led to his downfall, showing the danger of deceit.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:6-14 records Samson lying multiple times about his strength, which ultimately failed to protect him and led to betrayal.

questions.question: Based on Judges 16, what biblical principle can be applied to church life and fellowship?
options: Encouraging prayer and reliance on God strengthens the community in trials.
Ignoring prayer keeps the church strong.
Church life is about power and control.
questions.correctAnswer: Encouraging prayer and reliance on God strengthens the community in trials.
questions.explanation: Samson’s final prayer (Judges 16:28) illustrates the power of seeking God, a principle vital for church life and fellowship.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 teach about faithfulness and commitment in marriage and relationships?
options: Samson’s relationship with Delilah shows the danger of misplaced trust and the importance of faithfulness.
It is acceptable to trust anyone regardless of character.
Commitment is not important in relationships.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson’s relationship with Delilah shows the danger of misplaced trust and the importance of faithfulness.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:4-20 highlight how Delilah’s betrayal due to Samson’s misplaced trust led to his capture, teaching caution in relationships.

questions.question: How does Samson’s story in Judges 16 encourage believers to maintain hope through trials?
options: Despite blindness and imprisonment, Samson’s hair grew again, showing God’s ongoing care and hope.
Trials mean the end of God’s blessings.
There is no hope after failure.
questions.correctAnswer: Despite blindness and imprisonment, Samson’s hair grew again, showing God’s ongoing care and hope.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:21-22 show Samson’s hair grew after being shaven and imprisoned, symbolizing God’s faithfulness in hardship.

questions.question: How does Judges 16 show the importance of using God-given gifts for His glory and service to others?
options: Samson’s final act destroyed many enemies and delivered Israel, fulfilling God’s purpose despite personal failure.
Gifts should be used for personal gain only.
God’s gifts have no impact on others.
Strength is meant only for self-protection.
questions.correctAnswer: Samson’s final act destroyed many enemies and delivered Israel, fulfilling God’s purpose despite personal failure.
questions.explanation: Judges 16:28-30 shows Samson’s use of strength in obedience to God’s purpose to defeat the Philistines and deliver Israel.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 16.

questions.question: In Judges 16, what significant act of strength does Samson perform at midnight in Gaza?
options: He tears down the pillars of the temple
He carries away the city gates and posts on his shoulders
He kills a thousand Philistines with a jawbone
He uproots a tree and uses it as a weapon
questions.correctAnswer: He carries away the city gates and posts on his shoulders
questions.explanation: Judges 16:3 describes how Samson arose at midnight, took the doors of the gate of the city and the two posts, and carried them up on his shoulders to a hill before Hebron, showcasing his supernatural strength.

questions.question: What is the name of the woman Samson loved in the valley of Sorek?
questions.correctAnswer: Delilah
questions.explanation: Judges 16:4 identifies the woman Samson loved as Delilah, who later plays a pivotal role in his downfall.

questions.question: What was the reward offered by the lords of the Philistines to Delilah for discovering the source of Samson's strength?
options: Eleven hundred pieces of silver from each lord
questions.correctAnswer: Eleven hundred pieces of silver from each lord
questions.explanation: Judges 16:5 states that the Philistine lords promised Delilah eleven hundred pieces of silver from each of them if she could find out the secret of Samson’s strength.

questions.question: Which binding method did Samson claim would make him weak, involving seven green withs?
options: Binding with seven green withs that were never dried
Binding with ropes soaked in oil
questions.correctAnswer: Binding with seven green withs that were never dried
questions.explanation: In Judges 16:7, Samson says if he is bound with seven green withs that were never dried, he would become weak like another man.

questions.question: How did Samson respond when bound with seven green withs according to the chapter?
options: He broke them easily like a thread of tow burning
He called upon God to free him
He pretended to be weak but escaped at dawn
questions.correctAnswer: He broke them easily like a thread of tow burning
questions.explanation: Judges 16:9 explains that Samson broke the green withs as easily as a thread of tow is broken when it touches fire, showing his strength was not compromised.

questions.question: What did Samson say would make him weak the second time he told Delilah about his strength?
options: Binding with new ropes that had never been used
questions.correctAnswer: Binding with new ropes that had never been used
questions.explanation: Judges 16:11 indicates Samson told Delilah that binding him with new ropes that had never been occupied would make him weak.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the repeated attempts by Delilah to bind Samson and his repeated breaking free?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm illustrating increasing tension
questions.explanation: The repeated pattern of Delilah’s binding attempts and Samson’s breaking free (Judges 16:7–14) forms a chiasm, building narrative tension and emphasizing the eventual downfall.

questions.question: According to Judges 16, what was the true source of Samson's strength revealed to Delilah?
options: His uncut hair due to his Nazarite vow
questions.correctAnswer: His uncut hair due to his Nazarite vow
questions.explanation: Judges 16:17 reveals that Samson's strength lay in his uncut hair, a sign of his Nazarite dedication to God from birth.

questions.question: What cultural or religious practice does Samson’s Nazarite vow connect to in the broader biblical tradition?
options: A lifelong consecration to God involving abstentions
A ritual of purification before battle
An annual sacrifice to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: A lifelong consecration to God involving abstentions
questions.explanation: The Nazarite vow, referenced in Judges 16:17, involves lifelong dedication to God with abstentions from cutting hair, wine, and contact with the dead, as also described in Numbers 6.

questions.question: What happens to Samson after Delilah causes him to be shaven?
options: His strength leaves him, and he is captured and blinded by the Philistines
He prays and his strength returns
questions.correctAnswer: His strength leaves him, and he is captured and blinded by the Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 16:19-21 describe how once Samson’s hair was shaved, his strength left him; he was captured, blinded, and put to grind in prison.

questions.question: What is the significance of Samson’s hair beginning to grow again in prison?
options: It symbolizes the restoration of his strength and God’s favor
It shows his physical recovery but not spiritual
It indicates the passing of time
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the restoration of his strength and God’s favor
questions.explanation: Judges 16:22 notes Samson’s hair began to grow again, foreshadowing the return of his strength and God’s renewed empowerment for his final act.

questions.question: During the Philistine feast to their god Dagon, what does Samson request before destroying the temple?
options: Strength from the LORD to avenge his eyes
To be released and sent home
A final meal with his brethren
To speak to the Philistine lords
questions.correctAnswer: Strength from the LORD to avenge his eyes
questions.explanation: Judges 16:28 shows Samson calling on the LORD to remember him and give him strength once more to avenge his blinded eyes.

questions.question: What is the literary and theological significance of Samson’s final act of pulling down the pillars?
options: Typology of self-sacrifice and divine vengeance
Symbolizing Israel’s defeat by the Philistines
An allegory for the collapse of paganism
questions.correctAnswer: Typology of self-sacrifice and divine vengeance
questions.explanation: Samson’s destruction of the temple in Judges 16:29-30 serves as a typological foreshadowing of sacrificial atonement and divine judgment against enemies, highlighting God’s power working through flawed human agents.

questions.question: How long did Samson judge Israel according to the chapter's conclusion?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty years
questions.explanation: Judges 16:31 states that Samson judged Israel for twenty years, marking the duration of his leadership.

questions.question: True or False: The Philistines praised their god Dagon for delivering Samson into their hands, as seen in Judges 16.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Judges 16:23-24 explains that the Philistines rejoiced and praised Dagon because they believed their god had delivered Samson into their hand.

questions.question: What does the interaction between Samson and Delilah reveal about the nature of betrayal in the biblical narrative?
options: It illustrates the destructive power of personal weakness combined with external deceit
It shows that love always triumphs over conflict
It highlights the importance of political alliances
It depicts God’s rejection of human frailty
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the destructive power of personal weakness combined with external deceit
questions.explanation: The narrative in Judges 16 portrays how Samson’s emotional vulnerability and Delilah’s betrayal lead to his downfall, emphasizing the biblical theme of human frailty exploited by enemies.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the source of Samson's supernatural strength according to Judges 16?
questions.correctAnswer: His Nazirite vow to God
questions.explanation: Judges 16:17 reveals Samson's strength was tied to his Nazirite vow, which included not cutting his hair. This vow set him apart to God (Numbers 6:1-21). The New Testament also affirms God’s empowerment of believers (Acts 1:8). His strength was not from human sources but divine calling (1 Corinthians 1:27).

questions.question: What was Delilah's primary motivation for discovering the secret of Samson's strength?
options: She was bribed by the lords of the Philistines
She was testing his love for her
questions.correctAnswer: She was bribed by the lords of the Philistines
questions.explanation: Judges 16:5 shows the Philistine lords offered Delilah silver to reveal Samson's secret. This illustrates human sinfulness and betrayal (Psalm 41:9). It also demonstrates the spiritual battle between God's servant and worldly powers (Ephesians 6:12).

questions.question: What happened after Samson's hair was cut by Delilah?
options: He called on God for strength
questions.correctAnswer: His strength left him
questions.explanation: Judges 16:19-20 states that when Samson’s hair was shaved, his strength departed because he broke his Nazirite vow. This shows the connection between obedience to God and receiving His power (John 15:4-5). It also reflects the consequences of sin (Romans 6:23).

questions.question: How did Samson ultimately bring judgment upon the Philistines at his death?
options: By setting fire to their city
questions.correctAnswer: By collapsing the temple pillars
questions.explanation: Judges 16:29-30 records Samson pulling down the temple pillars, killing many Philistines. This act fulfills God’s judgment through His servant (Romans 12:19). It is a type of Christ’s victory over enemies (Colossians 2:15).

questions.question: What biblical theme is illustrated by Samson’s repeated deception of Delilah before revealing his secret?
options: The struggle between human weakness and divine purpose
The triumph of human wisdom over evil
questions.correctAnswer: The struggle between human weakness and divine purpose
questions.explanation: Samson’s lies (Judges 16:7-14) reflect the tension between his divine calling and his human failings. This theme of human weakness used by God is echoed in 2 Corinthians 12:9 and Romans 7:15-25. It demonstrates God's sovereignty despite human sin.

questions.question: What does Samson’s final prayer to God reveal about his faith?
options: He trusts God to restore strength for vengeance
He asks for forgiveness without faith
questions.correctAnswer: He trusts God to restore strength for vengeance
questions.explanation: In Judges 16:28, Samson calls on the LORD to remember and strengthen him for one last act of judgment. This shows faith in God's power to act even after failure, consistent with Psalm 51:10-12 and Hebrews 11:6.

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by the departure of the LORD from Samson after his hair was cut?
options: The presence of God depends on obedience and covenant faithfulness
Human strength is independent of God
God’s power is transferred to others automatically
questions.correctAnswer: The presence of God depends on obedience and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: Judges 16:20 shows that when Samson disobeyed his Nazirite vow, God’s Spirit departed from him, illustrating the biblical principle that God's presence is connected to faithfulness (Psalm 51:11, 1 Samuel 16:14). This aligns with 1 Corinthians 10:13 about faithfulness and consequences.

questions.question: How does Samson’s story in Judges 16 contribute to understanding human sin and redemption?
options: It shows God’s power to redeem flawed individuals
It teaches that sin results in permanent rejection
It promotes self-reliance over divine help
It suggests that strength is only physical
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s power to redeem flawed individuals
questions.explanation: Despite Samson’s failures, God uses him to defeat Israel’s enemies (Judges 16:30). This demonstrates God's grace and redemptive power over human sinfulness (Romans 5:8, 2 Corinthians 5:17). Samson’s life points forward to Christ’s perfect redemption.

questions.question: What does the Philistine celebration and sacrifice to Dagon imply about their worldview?
options: They believed their gods controlled victory in battle
They denied the existence of any gods
questions.correctAnswer: They believed their gods controlled victory in battle
questions.explanation: Judges 16:23-24 describes the Philistines offering a sacrifice to Dagon in thanks for capturing Samson, illustrating their belief in gods controlling events. This contrasts with the monotheistic faith in the LORD’s sovereignty (Deuteronomy 6:4, Isaiah 45:5).

questions.question: What does the mention that Samson judged Israel twenty years indicate about his role?
options: He was a deliverer and leader despite personal flaws
He was a king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He was a deliverer and leader despite personal flaws
questions.explanation: Judges 16:31 states Samson judged Israel for twenty years, signifying his role as God’s appointed deliverer (Hebrews 11:32-34). This shows God’s use of imperfect people for His purposes (1 Corinthians 1:27-29).

questions.question: What does the repeated motif of binding Samson in different ways before his capture signify about spiritual warfare?
options: The persistent efforts of evil forces to overcome God’s servant
The inevitability of human success without struggle
questions.correctAnswer: The persistent efforts of evil forces to overcome God’s servant
questions.explanation: Delilah’s repeated attempts to bind Samson (Judges 16:7-14) symbolize ongoing spiritual opposition (Ephesians 6:12). Despite this, Samson’s strength remained until divine departure, showing the tension in spiritual conflict (2 Corinthians 10:3-5).

questions.question: How does Samson’s story reflect the doctrine of the Holy Spirit’s role in empowering believers?
options: The Spirit empowers the believer but may depart if disobedience occurs
The Spirit is always present regardless of behavior
The Spirit is not involved in physical strength
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit empowers the believer but may depart if disobedience occurs
questions.explanation: Judges 16:20 shows the Spirit of the LORD left Samson when he disobeyed, indicating the Spirit’s empowering presence is conditional upon faithfulness (Isaiah 63:11-14, 1 Samuel 16:14). This aligns with New Testament teaching on the Spirit’s indwelling (Ephesians 5:18).

questions.question: What messianic theme can be drawn from Samson’s final act of sacrifice?
options: A suffering servant who defeats enemies through self-sacrifice
A conquering king who reigns in power
questions.correctAnswer: A suffering servant who defeats enemies through self-sacrifice
questions.explanation: Samson’s death by collapsing the temple pillars (Judges 16:30) prefigures Christ’s sacrificial death defeating evil (Isaiah 53, Hebrews 2:14-15). It highlights the motif of victory through suffering and sacrifice.

questions.question: What does the growth of Samson’s hair after it was shaved symbolize?
options: The potential for restoration and renewal
questions.correctAnswer: The potential for restoration and renewal
questions.explanation: Judges 16:22 notes Samson’s hair began to grow again, symbolizing hope for renewed strength and God’s ongoing work in restoration (Psalm 23:3, Lamentations 3:22-23). This reflects the biblical theme of repentance and renewal (2 Corinthians 5:17).

questions.question: What does the fact that Samson was brought to Gaza and put in prison reveal about the consequences of sin?
options: Sin leads to captivity and loss of freedom
Sin causes divine abandonment without consequence
Sin has no real impact on life
questions.correctAnswer: Sin leads to captivity and loss of freedom
questions.explanation: Judges 16:21 describes Samson being captured, blinded, and imprisoned, illustrating how sin leads to bondage and loss of liberty (Romans 6:16-18). This aligns with the biblical teaching that sin enslaves (John 8:34).

questions.question: How does Samson’s story in Judges 16 demonstrate God’s sovereignty over human history?
options: God uses even flawed individuals to accomplish His purposes
Human plans always prevail over God’s will
God is limited by human sin
God only acts through perfect people
questions.correctAnswer: God uses even flawed individuals to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Despite Samson’s flaws, God’s purpose was fulfilled (Judges 16:31). This shows God’s sovereignty in using imperfect people for His plans (Genesis 50:20, Romans 8:28). It affirms that God is in control of history regardless of human weakness.

questions.question: What does the interaction between Samson and Delilah teach about the nature of temptation and spiritual vulnerability?
options: Repeated pressure can lead even the strong to fall
Temptation is easily resisted by physical strength
Spiritual strength is unrelated to relationships
questions.correctAnswer: Repeated pressure can lead even the strong to fall
questions.explanation: Judges 16:15-16 shows Delilah’s persistent urging caused Samson’s soul to be vexed unto death, leading to his disclosure of the secret. This illustrates the biblical truth that temptation can wear down even the spiritually strong (1 Corinthians 10:13, James 1:14-15).
